awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Contact-aware Control of Dynamic Manipulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Working independently and in coordination with humans and other devices, intelligent robots have the potential for profound positive impact on society. To achieve this promise, robots must be fast, capable, and safe as they interact in complex, highly uncertain environments. In this context, the fundamental tasks of grasping and dexterous manipulation are critical: when robots touch their surroundings, they typically operate slowly and cautiously to avoid any accidental contact or damage. This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) research project will develop multi-purpose algorithms for dynamic grasping and manipulation to achieve human-like speed and effectiveness for a broad range of applications. For in-home assistive robots, for example, safety and speed are both important when manipulating either objects or people.  Prosthetic devices would also benefit from reliable and dynamic semi-autonomy: too often the control burden is placed on the user, who has limited sensing and actuation through the prosthetic interface. Additionally, both small and advanced manufacturing industries that require interaction with multiple tools and parts may benefit from this research. Outcomes of this research may also benefit robotic use in safety-critical applications, such as in disaster relief efforts.

A fundamental challenge in dexterous manipulation lies in the complexity of the contact between robot and object. Frictional contact introduces mathematical challenges to the governing equations of motion, particularly discontinuities which result in a combinatorial number of hybrid modes. This combinatorial complexity frustrates standard algorithmic methods, typically limiting manipulation schemes to a strict sequencing of contacts, defined a priori. This research has two central hypotheses. First, that formal, optimization-based numerical methods can discover and verify simple (non-combinatoric) control approaches that will be both dynamic and robust for unstructured manipulation tasks. This simplicity parallels human control of finger forces. Second, by explicitly considering the dynamics of manipulation, this research will lead to more robust and capable approaches than purely static or quasi-static methods. The algorithms will be implemented and tested on a physical, multi-link arm and gripper and in a simulated environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For robots of the future to be accepted by society as useful machines, whether working independently or in coordination with humans and other robots, they must be fast, capable, and safe. Furthermore, for in-home, workplace, and disaster recovery robots to be successful, they must function in complex, highly uncertain environments. Despite recent breakthroughs in control, computer vision, and machine learning, approaches to the fundamental tasks of grasping and dexterous manipulation in unstructured environments remain dominated by exceedingly cautious motion. While a great deal of focus has been placed on grasp selection, comparatively little research has focused on dynamically achieving a grasp and then performing a complex task with the grasped object. When robots must interact with objects, they typically operate slowly and cautiously, afraid that any accidental contact with the world, however minor, will result in failure.  This NRI project made advances toward general-purpose robots capable of rapidly pushing, grasping, and then utilizing objects (as tools, for instance) with human-like capabilities. 

 

Intellectual Merit

During the performance period of this project, significant progress on modeling and model-based control of dynamic manipulation has been made.

On the modeling front, theoretical results have led to an improved understanding of previously unsolvable multi-contact scenarios, including quasi-static modeling for grasping or pinching and simultaneous impact events which lead to multiple possible solutions. Empirical and computational results have both demonstrated that standard machine learning approaches are both theoretically and empirically doomed to poor data efficiency, and proposed a new physics-based approach to model learning.

Leveraging this improved understanding of non-smooth models for manipulation, this project made major advances in multi-contact control. Modeling robot-environment contact using local linearizations, as a Linear Complementarity System (LCS), provides a compact and computationally tractable (but hybrid) representation, amenable to control; the developed control design algorithm directly feeds back state and measured forces, verified as stable via convex optimization as a Semidefniite Programming (SDP), where control policies can be synthesized by solving a (nonconvex) Bilinear Matrix Inequality (BMI). 

These results, while providing guarantees of stability, required offline control synthesis. This thrust focused on real-time performance, with an understanding that achieving these rates will require suboptimal performance. A breakthrough in 2021 led to a consensus-based algorithm, rooted in the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM), called Consensus Complementarity Control (C3). C3 is the first algorithm to demonstrate real-time multi-contact model predictive control, deciding what to touch and when, and whether that contact should stick or slip. Results have been demonstrated across both simulated and physical platforms, including on a Franka Panda robotic arm, where this project demonstrated real-time control for dynamically manipulating a ball rolling on a surface. 

 

Broader Impacts

The results from this project have been published in a number of top venues, including RSS, ICRA, IROS, TRO, WAFR, RA-L, CoRL, and L4DC. One publication was named a finalist for Outstanding Dynamics and Control Paper at ICRA 2022. Source code and datasets have been released under open-source licenses and are available via the PIs website. The research results above represent substantial progress toward more dexterous and capable in-home and workplace roobts.

In coordination with the goals of this project, the co-orgainzed two workshops at RSS 2022: The Science of Bumping Into Things: Towards Robots That Aren't Afraid of Contact and Differentiable Simulation For Robotics, featuring talks from top researchers in the field, with 7 of the 17 invited talks from women.

The project has exposed a number of undergraduate and high school students ot research, some of whom have published publications (one as first author). Ph.D. students were actively involved in mentoring younger students, preparing the for future careers in academia and industry. Students funded under this project have also directly mentored two underrepresented high school students from Philadelphia Public Schools for summer research programs.
